p: Results from epidemiological and experimental studies strongly suggest that the use of medicinal plants or dietary supplements with bioactive plant-based extracts can have anti-inflammatory effects [ 233]. Contradictory results have been also reported [ 234]. Similarly, natural products from microalgae have been investigated for their anti-inflammatory properties. The most studied compounds are carotenoids, PUFAs, and modified carbohydrates [ 229, 235]. However, there are still many other microalgal metabolites that are also reported to suppress chronic inflammation and alleviate disease-associated symptoms, including phycobiliproteins, phenolic compounds, and various terpenoids [ 229, 236].
